info.game_comments:
2009 Tournament of Champions semifinal game 3.
From Las Vegas.

(1, 1).clue: Lots of chaps wear chaps in the Gaucho Parade in Salta in this country

(2, 1).clue: Jesus asked, if you have 100 of these animals & 1 is lost, don't you leave the 99 to go find the 1?

(3, 1).clue: Flat slab forming the top of a capital of a column (also an ancient calculator)

(4, 1).clue: The USA's Mariner 4 was the first probe to photograph the surface of this planet

(5, 1).clue: The Jolly guy in the logo for this veggie brand wears a one-shouldered leaf cloak

(1, 2).clue: Children are the chefs & waiters at the Kinderkookkafe in this world capital

(2, 2).clue: It's the sea in the line from Exodus "The sea covered them, they sank as lead in the mighty waters"

(3, 2).clue: Gallery or balcony open on at least one side (& actor Robert)

(4, 2).clue: Of a basketball, an SUV or a circus tent, the approximate size of Sputnik 1

(5, 2).clue: The logo of this French yogurt brand features a red & orange flower

(6, 2).clue: Arizona's Petrified Forest is mostly this type of tree that has 4 vowels in a row

(1, 3).clue: Have a 72-ounce steak at the Big Texan Steak Ranch in this Texas Panhandle city

(2, 3).clue: The last Psalm begins & ends, "Praise ye the Lord", a translation of this Hebrew word

(3, 3).clue: Stone laid on top of a wall from which an arch springs (it's also a season)

(4, 3).clue: In 1979 debris from the abandoned space station Skylab fell from orbit & dropped into this ocean

(5, 3).clue: This brand's keystone label includes its pickle insignia

(6, 3).clue: Shirley Hufstedler served under Jimmy Carter as the first Secretary of this department

(1, 4).clue: See one of Diego Rivera's last murals at the House of Dolores Olmedo in this resort city

(2, 4).clue: Paul wrote 2 Epistles to the Corinthians, 2 to the Thessalonians & 2 to this individual

(3, 4).clue: Projecting part of a cornice (& a Mexican beer)

(4, 4).clue: In 1998 Nozomi was this nation's first spacecraft sent to study another planet

(5, 4).clue: A perched mother bird is feeding her young in the logo of this Swiss conglomerate

(6, 4).clue: This word comes from the French for "self-movable"

(1, 5).clue: The stunning stretch of coastline between Sorrento & Salerno is called this "Coast"

(2, 5).clue: In John, this high priest says, "One man should die for the people, and... the whole nation perish not"

(3, 5).clue: Monumental temple gateway in ancient Egypt (also a Faulkner novel) (Bonus: & an orange traffic cone)

(4, 5).clue: Greek name of NASA's series of probes launched in the mid-'70s to study the Sun

(5, 5).clue: This mammal is in the Bacardi Rum logo

(6, 5).clue: FEMA says to keep a full tank of gas in your car if this order seems likely

(1, 1).clue: Mendelssohn put this Italian word for a brisk tempo on the first movement of his "Italian" symphony

(3, 1).clue: His novel "Sister Carrie" sold fewer than 500 copies in its first edition

(4, 1).clue: A Cuban 1-peso note shows Jose Marti on the obverse & this man entering Havana in 1959 on the reverse

(5, 1).clue: Urging his execution, in 1792 Robespierre said this king "must perish because our country must live!"

(6, 1).clue: It means "to the point of making one sick"

(1, 2).clue: Joseph Rheinberger played this instrument for his parish church at age 7 & wrote 2 notable sonatas for it

(2, 2).clue: ...about a witch who was once married to Attila the Hun

(3, 2).clue: This experimental novelist named William published a 1953 account of drug addiction under the name William Lee

(4, 2).clue: This country's $50 bill features William Lyon Mackenzie King, its longest-serving prime minister

(5, 2).clue: A busy guy, he was King of Italy (1900 to 1946), Emperor of Ethiopia (1936 to 1941) & King of Albania (1939 to 1943)

(6, 2).clue: Literally "rare bird", it's used today to describe something very unusual

(1, 3).clue: A 1725 notebook of compositions by this Baroque master bears the name of a wife who bore him 13 children

(2, 3).clue: ...named for the character seen here (don't forget his degree)

(3, 3).clue: This novel by Richard Wright tells of Bigger Thomas, the product of a Chicago slum

(4, 3).clue: Pitcairn Island & the Cook Islands use this country's dollar as their currency

(5, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the "magical" Rosenborg Castle in Copenhagen, Denmark.) Denmark's fourth king of this name was a notable builder who contributed to the plans of Rosenborg Castle, constructed in the early 1600s as his summer home

(6, 3).clue: Be careful at the Roman flea market & remember this, Latin for "buyer beware"

(1, 4).clue: "Blessed are they that go mourning" is the opening chorus of Brahms' "German" this

(3, 4).clue: This series of tales by Ovid with a plural title begins with the creation of the world

(4, 4).clue: This country's 1,000-pound notes feature Hafez al-Assad & scenes depicting its oil industry

(5, 4).clue: This country's King Bhumbol was born in Cambridge, Mass., where his father was studying at Harvard

(6, 4).clue: It's the legal phrase meaning "friend of the court"

(1, 5).clue: Richard Chamberlain played him in "The Music Lovers", which featured his piano concerto No. 1, heard here

(2, 5).clue: ...seen here & often called the greatest ever produced

(3, 5).clue: Isabel Archer is the title woman of this Henry James masterpiece

(4, 5).clue: In 1999 Denmark honored this author of "Out of Africa" by featuring her on the 50-kroner bill

(5, 5).clue: Killed in battle in 1031, this king of Norway was made a saint in 1164

(6, 5).clue: This phrase means "there's no accounting for taste"

(0, 0).clue: Of the 6 Civil War-related national military parks, the northernmost & southernmost are in these 2 states
